unnormalised: Someone asked me about typical grocery bills in Mumbai. It really depends on your lifestyle, right? A bachelor living alone might spend around Rs. 3000-Rs. 5000 a month if they're mostly eating out and just grabbing essentials like bread, milk (1 litre usually lasts me 3 days), and maybe some Maggi.
normalised: Someone asked me about typical grocery bills in Mumbai. It really depends on your lifestyle, right? A bachelor living alone might spend around rupee three thousand to rupee five thousand a month if they are mostly eating out and just grabbing essentials like bread, milk (one liter usually lasts me three days), and maybe some Maggi.

unnormalised: A family of 4, though, will definitely be looking at a higher spend. I'd say a reasonable estimate for a family buying fresh produce, dairy, rice, dals, and other staples would be Rs. 8000-Rs. 15000 per month. This is assuming you're shopping at local markets or maybe a place like D-Mart. Supermarkets like Nature's Basket will obviously push that number up. And organic stuff? Forget about it, add another 25%.
normalised: A family of four, though, will definitely be looking at a higher spend. I would say a reasonable estimate for a family buying fresh produce, dairy, rice, dals, and other staples would be rupee eight thousand to rupee fifteen thousand per month. This is assuming you are shopping at local markets or maybe a place like D-Mart. Supermarkets like Nature's Basket will obviously push that number up. And organic stuff? Forget about it, add another twenty five percent.

unnormalised: Online shopping is also a big factor. Sites like Bigbasket or Blinkit are convenient, but they often have promotional discounts. You can easily save ₹ 500 on your first order and another ₹ 200 using some coupon codes. Just remember to compare prices with your local kirana store before you get too reliant on online options, especially for everyday items like sugar (1kg) or salt (also 1 kg).
normalised: Online shopping is also a big factor. Sites like Bigbasket or Blinkit are convenient, but they often have promotional discounts. You can easily save rupee five hundred on your first order and another rupee two hundred using some coupon codes. Just remember to compare prices with your local kirana store before you get too reliant on online options, especially for everyday items like sugar (one kilogram) or salt (also one kilogram).

unnormalised: Ultimately, budgeting for groceries is a personal thing. Track your expenses for a month, see where your money is going, and then adjust accordingly. Don't forget to factor in those spontaneous "chocolate cravings" that cost about Rs. 150. Hope this helps!
normalised: Ultimately, budgeting for groceries is a personal thing. Track your expenses for a month, see where your money is going, and then adjust accordingly. Do not forget to factor in those spontaneous "chocolate cravings" that cost about rupee one hundred and fifty. Hope this helps!
